awd_titl_txt: RCN-UBE:  Data-to-Design Course-based Undergraduate Research Experience ? protein modeling and characterization to enhance student learning and improve computational protein design
awd_abstract_narration:
Incorporating undergraduate research experiences into laboratory courses vastly increases the reach and accessibility of these opportunities. The Data-to-Design Course-based Undergraduate Research Experience (D2D-CURE) network will train and support faculty to broaden research participation and expand high-impact educational practices. The network is designed to make this workflow accessible to a wide array of higher education institutions (community colleges, state schools, liberal arts schools, as well as research universities), as a high-impact module for existing and new biochemistry and bioengineering courses. Collectively and over time students who engage in this project will be generating datasets large enough to begin utilizing machine learning tools to improve protein design algorithms, while learning translatable skills, the process of science, and developing confidence in doing research. This network serves to both train future scientist and to advance the progress of science.

The Data-to-Design Course-based Undergraduate Research Experience (D2D-CURE) network's primary goal is to make a well-developed and tested molecular modeling and enzyme characterization workflow accessible to institutions nation-wide as an integratable curricular element for existing and new biology courses. The project has three major activities: The first is the coordination of workshops that will enable instructors from across the country to employ the D2D-CURE workshop at their home institutions. The second is the expansion of an annual conference, currently focused on protein modeling and design, to include a student development and engagement track. Third is the development of an online presence allowing the D2D-CURE participants to work in concert on cutting-edge scientific problems as a community as opposed to isolated institutions and programs. Despite widespread adoption of computational protein design, significant improvements are still needed to move efforts from being a tool used to enrich proteins with the desired function into a more accurate and predictive computer-aided design tool with a quantitative relationship between design and desired function. We plan to focus on enzymes since the only large data sets that currently exist are not quantitative, have a low dynamic range, and often convolve several independent physical measurements into a single value. To generate the data sets needed to develop a new generation of computational protein design software for enzymes, we are proposing a Research Coordination Network to engage students and their instructors in using industrially relevant techniques while generating acutely needed protein structure-function datasets.

This project is being jointly funded by the Directorate for Biological Sciences, Division of Biological Infrastructure, and the Directorate for Education and Human Resources, Division of Undergraduate Education as part of their efforts to address the challenges posed in Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education: A Call to Action (http://visionandchange/finalreport/).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Ideating and implementing undergraduate learning opportunities that advance research progress is challenging. Course-based Undergraduate Research Experiences (CUREs) that are nationally networked and have a common research goal address this challenge by providing the creative and logistical infrastructure for faculty to plug into. This project supported incubation of a new biotechnology-focused CURE that can readily serve as the comprehensive lab practicum for cell, molecular, microbiology, and biochemistry courses from freshman to senior level classes at any institution. Such broad adaptability was realized by the collaborative efforts of a small network of early adopter faculty supported by this project. The team developed a modular workflow that engages students in a series of cutting-edge techniques sought after by biotech employers and advanced degree programs. Moreover, the research goal enhances the students experience by adding direct meaning to their work on the project. Students are collecting data with the aim of elucidating structure to function relationship in proteins, which remains a holy grail in the field, particularly as the sequence-to-structure relationship by some measures is solved. The stakeholder community connection to this network makes the D2D CURE unique; the research direction of the project is informed by the Rosetta Commons, an international protein modeling and design consortium. The data generated by the students will be used to train protein modeling software to more accurately predict function. Improvements in in-silico model accuracy will translate to huge gains in efficiency in the wet-lab to engineer proteins to tackle todays grand challenges.

The research goal of the D2D CURE is central to the students experience because the relevance enhances their sense of project ownership. This sense of ownership has been shown to be the most important mitigating factor in students research career intentions. We investigated student attitudes and non-cognitive developments that have been linked to STEM persistence and observed significant gains in measures of scientific self-efficacy and networking and engagement, indicating that the D2D CURE experience confers validated benefits to students. We surveyed our network faculty for their perceptions of alignment of ASBMB learning objectives and D2D CURE modules; faculty found strongest alignment between Skills and Competencies, Structure and Function, Biological Information Flow objectives. Together, these assessments provide a foundation for deeper evaluation and the positive outcomes serve as a justification for program success at the end of this project incubation stage.

Integrating institutions with limited research resources into the network proved to be a critical challenge uncovered in this project. Our network team was comprised of three R1 and six liberal arts and comprehensive colleges, and three community colleges. The community colleges onboard were particularly creative securing resource opportunities prior to joining the network. We found it was essential to have a well-resourced team, able to take extra time and spend extra funds to pilot and drive the early developments of the program at this stage. However, we recognize that making the network more accessible to new members who are less resourced is critical for reaching students who will benefit most from this experience.

Beyond the Siegel Lab undergraduate training program and D2D classes offered at UC Davis, this project supported the course adoption by twelve other institutions nation-wide during this project. Between 2018-2020, 184 students have participated in D2D courses. Looking forward, we expect our network to grow and we expect to serve over thousands of students. Facilitated by our growing team, the underlying scientific goal of D2D is to engage academic crowd-sourcing to rapidly address protein design questions that would normally take isolated labs decades to answer. The educational research goal is to create a mechanism to confer the benefits of undergraduate research in a format that any institution can access. The mission of the project is to provide students with opportunities that shape their careers and open doors to their future success.

This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.


Last Modified: 11/22/2021
Modified by: Justin Siegel
